awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Effects of High Impact Engagement Activities at Land Grant Universities on Engineering Student Participation, Persistence, and Success
awd_abstract_narration:
The engineering profession is crucial to the innovation economy. Yet despite the career opportunities it offers, a high proportion of undergraduate students that enter engineering colleges do not complete an engineering degree. Student perseverance, retention and graduation rates remain grand challenges in engineering education, especially among women, underrepresented minority group members, and nontraditional students. Although many factors contribute to student success, there is research evidence suggesting that students are more likely to persist and be successful when they are involved in "high impact engagement activities." These include (but are not limited to) undergraduate research, entrepreneurship programs, study abroad programs, service learning opportunities, and creative, collaborative experiences. Despite this evidence, only a fraction of engineering students take advantage of these opportunities which remain largely voluntary and potentially inaccessible for diverse or nontraditional students. The long-term goal of this research is to broaden the effects of high-impact engagement activities on student perseverance and student success among engineering undergraduate students, including women, underrepresented minority group members, and nontraditional students. The objectives of this project are to: (1) identify those factors that affect engineering student participation in high impact engagement activities; (2) examine how to broaden the participation in such activities through improved student awareness and access across gender, racial, ethnic, age, and socio-economic boundaries; and (3) build engineering education research capacity at Washington State University in order to better respond to the engineering profession's current and emerging needs for an innovative and inclusive workforce. The products of this research will include: (1) a better understanding of the relationships, if any, between participation in high impact engagement activities and engineering student perseverance and success, including specifically among diverse or nontraditional students, as well as the factors affecting student participation (e.g., lack of awareness/interest, time constraints, financial or social/family constraints); and (2) evidence-based recommendations on how to make high impact engagement activities more accessible, especially to nontraditional students, women, and underrepresented minority group members. These results will be disseminated in the form of a report and through publications in peer-reviewed higher education journals and engineering conference proceedings. The third product will be the establishment of an active and sustained engineering education research program partnership between Washington State University, which does not have a formal engineering education program, and Utah State University, which does have a formal program.

This project will specifically contribute new understandings of the current status of student participation in high impact engagement activities in rural, land grant settings. Because there is limited research on engineering (and computer science) undergraduate education within rural land-grant university settings, this work is potentially transformative, as it could add new understanding about this less-well researched setting. To achieve these goals, the project will examine, through surveys and focus group interviews, the following: (1) to what extent engineering and computer science students at two rural, land grant universities participate in high impact engagement activities; (2) how participation in these activities is correlated to student outcomes; (3) what factors (i.e., personal, social, institutional, financial, etc.) affect student awareness, interest, and participation among engineering and computer science students in these activities, specifically at rural, land grant universities; and (4) how individual factors (i.e., personal, social, institutional, financial, etc.) influence student awareness, interest, and participation rates. A two-phase, explanatory, sequential, mixed-methods research design will be used. Analysis of qualitative (focus group interviews) and quantitative (survey) data will result in new understandings concerning ways to increase participation of engineering and computer science students in high impact engagement activities, within rural, land grant, public university settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary purpose of this  project was to broaden the effects of high-impact engagement activities on student persistence and student success among engineering and computer science undergraduate students, including women and underrepresented minority group members. These high-impact activities include, but are not limited to, undergraduate research, entrepreneurship programs, study abroad, service learning, and creative capstone experiences. Research goals included developing and disseminating evidence-based recommendations for implementation of high impact engagement activities based on a combination of survey results and focus group interviews conducted at two rural, land grant universities: Washington State University (WSU) and Utah State University (USU). A secondary goal of this project was to build engineering education capacity at land grant institutions generally, and Washington State University (WSU) specifically, through an active and sustained research collaboration among engineering faculty within WSU?s Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture (VCEA); education faculty and students within WSU?s College of Education; and engineering education faculty and graduate students within the Department of Engineering Education at Utah State University (USU).

To achieve these goals, this project examined: (1) to what extent engineering and computer science students at these two universities participate in high impact engagement activities; (2) how participation in these activities is correlated to student outcomes; (3) what factors (i.e., personal, social, institutional, financial, etc.) affect student awareness, interest, and participation among engineering and computer science students in these activities, specifically at rural, land grant universities; and (4) how individual factors (i.e., personal, social, institutional, financial, etc.) influence student awareness, interest, and participation rates. A two-phase, explanatory, sequential, mixed-methods research design was used. Analysis of qualitative (focus group interviews) and quantitative (survey) data resulted in new understandings concerning ways to increase participation by engineering and computer science students in high impact engagement activities, within rural, land grant, public university settings.

Intellectual Merit

Student persistence and success remain as challenges in E/CS education, especially among women and underrepresented minority group members. Although many factors contribute to student success, there is research evidence that suggests that students are more likely to persist and be successful when they are involved in HIEA (Kuh, 2008). Yet despite this evidence, only a fraction of E/CS students take advantage of these opportunities which remain largely voluntary and potentially inaccessible for diverse undergraduates. Past research on high impact engagement activities (HIEA) has focused on areas other than E/CS, resulting in a substantial gap that this project addressed.

In this study, involvement in internships was the most common HIEA in which E/CS students participated. Among the HIEAs examined, participation in study abroad programs was the least common activity in which E/CS students were involved, although some demographic groups (notably Hispanic/LatinX students) were more interested than other groups in global learning and study abroad opportunities. Institutional barriers to participation in HIEAs were noted by some groups (notably, first-generation students). Students commonly noted valuing authentic, practical, and hands-on experiences that could be offered by HIEAs. Students were unaware of service and community-based opportunities.

In a multifactor analysis, involvement in HIEAs was found to be statistically correlated to academic achievement goals, interest, and persistence. This analysis also suggested that students may be more inclined to participate in HIEA if they have the opportunity to personalize such activities to be aligned with their interests, and this in turn may increase positive learning outcomes and retention rates. Practically speaking, students that set academic achievement goals and participate in compatible HIEA are more likely to persist and achieve positive learning outcomes than students that participate in HIEA without the benefit of having set career goals and tailoring their HIEA to be compatible with those goals.

Broader Impacts

Despite ongoing efforts to improve science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate persistence and success, retention of engineering and computer science students, especially among women and underrepresented group members, has not changed significantly over the past decade. Participation in HIEAs such as internships, undergraduate research, study abroad programs, service or community based opportunities, and student clubs, provides the authentic, practical, hands-on experiences that are valued by students. To optimize the efficacy of involvement in HIEA and thus increase student persistence, retention and success, students should set academic achievement goals and seek HIEA opportunities that are aligned with those goals.

The faculty plays an important role for creating awareness and excitement in HIEA, and they should encourage students to set academic achievement goals and identify HIEA that support those goals. Colleges should make opportunities for such activities more apparent, and adequate resources including funding should be made available for implementation of appropriate HIEA.


Last Modified: 11/06/2023
Modified by: Candis S Claiborn
por.por_txt_cntn:
The primary purpose of this project was to broaden the effects of  high-impact engagement activities on student persistence and student  success among engineering and computer science undergraduate students,  including women and underrepresented minority group members. These  high-impact activities include, but are not limited to, undergraduate  research, entrepreneurship programs, study abroad, service learning, and  creative capstone experiences. Research goals included developing and  disseminating evidence-based recommendations for implementation of high  impact engagement activities based on a combination of survey results  and focus group interviews conducted at two rural, land grant  universities: Washington State University (WSU) and Utah State  University (USU). A secondary goal of this project was to build  engineering education capacity at land grant institutions generally, and  Washington State University (WSU) specifically, through an active and  sustained research collaboration among engineering faculty within WSU?s  Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture (VCEA); education  faculty and students within WSU?s College of Education; and engineering  education faculty and graduate students within the Department of  Engineering Education at Utah State University (USU).


To achieve  these goals, this project examined: (1) to what extent engineering and  computer science students at these two universities participate in high  impact engagement activities;(2) how participation in these activities  is correlated to student outcomes; (3) what factors (i.e., personal,  social, institutional, financial, etc.) affect student awareness,  interest, and participation among engineering and computer science  students in these activities, specifically at rural, land grant  universities; and (4) how individual factors (i.e., personal, social,  institutional, financial, etc.) influence student awareness, interest,  and participation rates. A two-phase, explanatory, sequential,  mixed-methods research design was used. Analysis of qualitative (focus  group interviews) and quantitative (survey) data resulted in new  understandings concerning ways to increase participation by engineering  and computer science students in high impact engagement activities,  within rural, land grant, public university settings.


Intellectual Merit


Student  persistence and success remain as challenges in E/CS education,  especially among women and underrepresented minority group members.  Although many factors contribute to student success, there is research  evidence that suggests that students are more likely to persist and be  successful when they are involved in HIEA (Kuh, 2008). Yet despite this  evidence, only a fraction of E/CS students take advantage of these  opportunities which remain largely voluntary and potentially  inaccessible for diverse undergraduates. Past research on high impact  engagement activities (HIEA) has focused on areas other than E/CS,  resulting in a substantial gap that this project addressed.


In  this study, involvement in internships was the most common HIEA in which  E/CS students participated. Among the HIEAs examined, participation in  study abroad programs was the least common activity in which E/CS  students were involved, although some demographic groups (notably  Hispanic/LatinX students) were more interested than other groups in  global learning and study abroad opportunities. Institutional barriers  to participation in HIEAs were noted by some groups (notably,  first-generation students). Students commonly noted valuing authentic,  practical, and hands-on experiences that could be offered by HIEAs.  Students were unaware of service and community-based opportunities.


In  a multifactor analysis, involvement in HIEAs was found to be  statistically correlated to academic achievement goals, interest, and  persistence. This analysis also suggested that students may be more  inclined to participate in HIEA if they have the opportunity to  personalize such activities to be aligned with their interests, and this  in turn may increase positive learning outcomes and retention rates.  Practically speaking, students that set academic achievement goals and  participate in compatible HIEA are more likely to persist and achieve  positive learning outcomes than students that participate in HIEA  without the benefit of having set career goals and tailoring their HIEA  to be compatible with those goals. 



Broader Impacts


Despite  ongoing efforts to improve science, technology, engineering, and  mathematics (STEM) undergraduate persistence and success, retention of  engineering and computer science students, especially among women and  underrepresented group members, has not changed significantly over the  past decade. Participation in HIEAs such as internships, undergraduate  research, study abroad programs, service or community based  opportunities, and student clubs, provides the authentic, practical,  hands-on experiences that are valued by students. To optimize the  efficacy of involvement in HIEA and thus increase student persistence,  retention and success, students should set academic achievement goals  and seek HIEA opportunities that are aligned with those goals.


The  faculty plays an important role for creating awareness and excitement  in HIEA, and they should encourage students to set academic achievement  goals and identify HIEA that support those goals. Colleges should make  opportunities for such activities more apparent, and adequate resources  including funding should be made available for implementation of  appropriate HIEA.
